CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. Dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT)
2. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
3. Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS)
4. PC 70 BM ([6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester)
5. Electron-rich donor units
6. Electron-deficient acceptor units

These are the material names mentioned in the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. Dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT)
2. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
3. PC 70 BM ([6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester)
4. Electron-rich donor units
5. Electron-deficient acceptor units

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. The band gap of POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers is approximately 900 nm. To convert this to eV, we can use the following formula:

E = hc/λ

where E is energy, h is Planck's constant (4.135667696 × 10^-15 eV s), c is the speed of light (2.99792458 × 10^8 m/s), and λ is wavelength in meters.

900 nm = 900 × 10^-9 m

E = (4.135667696 × 10^-15 eV s) × (2.99792458 × 10^8 m/s) / (900 × 10^-9 m)

E = 1.39 eV

However, the text mentions that the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ~900 nm, but it does not explicitly state that the band gap of the polymers is 900 nm. Therefore, the value of 900 nm may not directly refer to the band gap of the polymers.

2. The HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) level of both POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers is -5.3 eV.
3. The LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) level of both POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers is -4.0 eV.
4. The open-circuit voltage (Voc) of POBDTPD devices is 0.70 V.
5. The short-circuit current density (Jsc) of POBDTPD devices is 10.6 mA/cm^2.
6. The fill factor (FF) of POBDTPD devices is 0.64.
7. The open-circuit voltage (Voc) of PEBDTPD devices is 0.72 V.
8. The short-circuit current density (Jsc) of PEBDTPD devices is 13.5 mA/cm^2.
9. The fill factor (FF) of PEBDTPD devices is 0.54.
10. The higher carrier mobility in the polymer:PC 70 BM blend films is attributed to the PEBDTPD polymer.

Therefore, the identified values (number + unit) of material properties in the paragraph are:

* Band gap of polymers: ~900 nm (unsure if this refers to the band gap)
* HOMO level of polymers: -5.3 eV
* LUMO level of polymers: -4.0 eV
* Open-circuit voltage (Voc) of POBDTPD devices: 0.70 V
* Short-circuit current density (Jsc) of POBDTPD devices: 10.6 mA/cm^2
* Fill factor (FF) of POBDTPD devices: 0.64
* Open-circuit voltage (Voc) of PEBDTPD devices: 0.72 V
* Short-circuit current density (Jsc) of PEBDTPD devices: 13.5 mA/cm^2
* Fill factor (FF) of PEBDTPD devices: 0.54
* Carrier mobility in the polymer:PC 70 BM blend films: higher for PEBDTPD polymer.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

* Band gap of polymers: ~900 nm (unsure if this refers to the band gap)
* HOMO level of polymers: -5.3 eV
* LUMO level of polymers: -4.0 eV
* Open-circuit voltage (Voc) of POBDTPD devices: 0.70 V
* Short-circuit current density (Jsc) of POBDTPD devices: 10.6 mA/cm2
* Fill factor (FF) of POBDTPD devices: 0.64
* Open-circuit voltage (Voc) of PEBDTPD devices: 0.72 V
* Short-circuit current density (Jsc) of PEBDTPD devices: 13.5 mA/cm2
* Fill factor (FF) of PEBDTPD devices: 0.54
* Carrier mobility in the polymer:PC 70 BM blend films: higher for PEBDTPD polymer.

Note: I'm not sure if the band gap of polymers refers to the band gap or not, so I included it with a disclaimer.
